children.tweet: @disruptivedean do you know that internet is best effort? Have you heard this? @karimlesina @ATT
@lgambardella I do. Whereas you clearly do not; eg your frequent pronouncements on nonsense like sender-pays. I confront clients' prejudices
@lgambardella About what? I'm universally known as being an outspoken & contrarian analyst. What else would you like me to talk about?
@disruptivedean you should be more transparent
@lgambardella You have a problem arguing on the basis of facts & technology, when you're unable to blame conflicts of interests, it seems
@disruptivedean so, if you work for telcos and vendors you should know how does it work @karimlesina
@karimlesina Still doesn't address what happens if asymmetry is other way. Ultimately it's all driven by AT&T's customers & price they pay
@disruptivedean you got the point
@karimlesina Which other posts? That article is mostly a polemic, with the possible exception of aspects of peering relationships
@disruptivedean @lgambardella you should read the entire blog. I think there is no real strange request. Let's comment the real facts here
@lgambardella @karimlesina Mostly telcos and mid/large network vendors
@lgambardella ironically I don't have @ATT as client as it spends too much money on lobbying & not enough on its ancient procurement system
@disruptivedean I mean, @lgambardella @karimlesina @att have a near monopoly in a growing market and all they can do is whine about it.
@disruptivedean Amused that @lgambardella @karimlesina @att still think "internet == telecom" bizarre this misconception still exists.
@lgambardella Among my clients: Orange, GSMA, Ericsson, Belgacom, T-Mobile, Radisys, IBM, ALU, NTT, SingTel, Verizon, Huawei, OMA etc
@disruptivedean could you please reveal the name of your customers? Or is a secret?
@lgambardella I've answered multiple times. My clients are predominantly telcos & vendors. Including about 7 ETNO members
@lgambardella Most are on http://t.co/JGf45qpVed . Many are tech winners (eg WebRTC) & losers (NFC, RCS). Also importance of #netneutrality
@lgambardella I do indeed know, yes. Although it's a bit of a misnomer. Here it means that video data traffic is not treated differently
@disruptivedean you should know what best effort means
@lgambardella @disruptivedean Yeah, you need enough 'quality' to prevent your customers leaving. Not having competition makes this easier.
@lgambardella Quality has multiple dimensions. Some are more important than others. Eg mobile coverage is critical, as is customer service
@lgambardella conversely, managed per-app Internet QoS is not required (& probably impossible in most cases anyway)
@disruptivedean so we don't need any quality
@lgambardella Generally yes. Also worth noting that many of your telco members *also* sell video or music over best-effort Internet
@disruptivedean if they are happy with best effort
@lgambardella What's your evidence? Boeing will sell me a 747 ordered over the Internet. Amazon, Apple or Netflix will sell me a movie
RT @disruptivedean: @lgambardella It's funny, but I say same about you. The telecom sector needs to change. Wishful thinking & delay just m…
@lgambardella It's funny, but I say same about you. The telecom sector needs to change. Wishful thinking & delay just makes it more painful
RT @lgambardella: @disruptivedean with your strange advices you will destroy the whole sector
RT @lgambardella: @disruptivedean with your strange advices you will destroy the whole sector

@disruptivedean with your strange advices you will destroy the whole sector
@lgambardella If you want me to work with ETNO to help you understand all this, I'll give you a better price & more insight than ATKearney
RT @lgambardella: @disruptivedean so you have solved all the problems. You are more than an oracle
RT @lgambardella: @disruptivedean so you have solved all the problems. You are more than an oracle
@disruptivedean so you have solved all the problems. You are more than an oracle
@lgambardella I pay my licence fee for TV in UK. And I'm happy with BBC iPlayer over best-effort Internet
@disruptivedean if you "sell" (means ask money to the customers) video over the internet you can't rely on best effort.
@lgambardella Is that just an assertion, or your analysis from working with Internet video companies? Which content co's do you speak to?
@lgambardella Be transparent. Which content & video companies have told you they're unwilling to use best-effort Internet?
@disruptivedean if you "sell" video over the internet you can't rely on best effort.
@lgambardella Of course I understand. And when I speak to video (or voice) companies, many are happy with variable quality & best effort
@lgambardella What they are wary of is deliberately worse-than-best effort. Or "no effort"
@lgambardella ... or cynical dimensioning & configuration of networks to be "just slightly too bad". It's pretty easy to spot
@lgambardella @disruptivedean Yup, and most of the time it exceeds the experience I'd get from a gtee'd service of the same cost.
RT @steely_glint: @lgambardella @disruptivedean In other words I accept a more variable service with a higher average quality. See @marting…
@martingeddes @steely_glint @lgambardella "a" not "the". Along with devices, billing, giving access to something customers find useful etc
@martingeddes @steely_glint A very large % telecom revenues derives from "just turning up" rather than any specific performance
@martingeddes @steely_glint I think you want to check the difference in meaning between "performance" and "ignorance" and "existence"
@martingeddes @disruptivedean @steely_glint Not to mention, if it isn't, then I have no means of judging roaming services accurately.
@martingeddes @disruptivedean @steely_glint Uhh, I would expect it to be explicitly qualified. After all, it is for domestic services.
@disruptivedean @steely_glint Your false assumption is that this performance has to be explicitly quantified. Implicitly always needed.
@martingeddes @steely_glint Ah, but QoE would be determined by velvet gloves, bowing/scraping & relative politeness of butler vs. postie
@steely_glint @disruptivedean They would also be valueless, at the speed of butler; not enough performance to compete against postal service
@disruptivedean @martingeddes Or in other words, even if roaming packets were hand delivered by a butler they would _still_ be too expensive
@det_conan_kudo @disruptivedean @martingeddes Actually it is spreading, within Europe rates are manageable, + three  to USA
@steely_glint @disruptivedean @martingeddes But T-Mobile US is the exception that pretty much proves the rule. No one else does that.
@steely_glint @disruptivedean @martingeddes We're seeing it fade away a little bit, and some MNOs are describing perf+price. Ex. TMUS.
@det_conan_kudo @disruptivedean @martingeddes Yep. Plus the fact that it makes money, so like toll fraud it remains.
@disruptivedean @martingeddes @steely_glint But it's only that way due to artificial decisions imposed upon us long ago by the MNOs...
RT @quinta: @disruptivedean give a try to messagenet talk voip app. it uses obfuscation to avoid being filtered by MNOs.
@disruptivedean give a try to messagenet talk voip app. it uses obfuscation to avoid being filtered by MNOs.
@disruptivedean you can associate a "landline" number. setup call forwarding from your mobile to this "landline" number.
RT @quinta: @disruptivedean go abroad and get a local data-only SIM and you receive mobile calls, to your original phone number, on your mo…
@disruptivedean go abroad and get a local data-only SIM and you receive mobile calls, to your original phone number, on your mobile
@martingeddes @steely_glint For roaming, 2.5G & WiFi is mostly fine, yes. Domestically, raw speed (& startup time) performance is valuable
@disruptivedean @steely_glint In that case, it was a mistake to build 3G and 4G networks, since performance is irrelevant to payment.
@martingeddes @steely_glint No, wrong. If I don't get *price* I need, I stop paying. And, indeed, have done. Performance not a consideration
@disruptivedean @steely_glint If you don't get the performance you need, you stop paying. Hence sole sustainable source of network value.
@disruptivedean @steely_glint Also, the wholesaler has to compete for biz from retailers. Network coverage, performance will both matter.
@martingeddes @steely_glint Never seen a roaming price table telling me what performance to expect, or right-of-redress if I don't get it
@steely_glint @disruptivedean Yet people still pay - because the performance it offers has enough value.
@disruptivedean @martingeddes Roaming data has no gtee - except excessive prices.
@martingeddes @steely_glint Not to mention that highest prices are charged where telco has no way to measure/grntee performance (roaming)
@disruptivedean @steely_glint Clue is in the name: "telecommunications". Spend capital on network, deliver & capture value from performance.
@martingeddes @steely_glint No more or less important than data-centre cooling, sapphire glass for screens, UI design, battery chemistry etc
@disruptivedean @steely_glint @lgambardella Try delivering value without it! It is the very essence and purpose of our industry.
@martingeddes @steely_glint @lgambardella & 100 other factors driving "app value". Network perf is not a special flower in that equation
@steely_glint @lgambardella @disruptivedean Seems you need a shared & robust model of how value, QoE and network performance truly relate.
@lgambardella @disruptivedean In other words I accept a more variable service with a higher average quality. See @martingeddes 's deltaQ .
@steely_glint @disruptivedean but is best effort
@lgambardella @disruptivedean \n"You can't rely on best effort" And yet somehow I get most of my 'tv' and calls over the internet.
@disruptivedean If you sell a video over the internet you want be sure of the quality. You can't rely on best effort. I hope you understand
@lgambardella Why not? Plenty of software tools to assist, eg adaptive codecs, pre-emotive downloads, WiFi sideloads etc. Works well
@lgambardella plus, "video" covers 1000s of different apps, use-cases & formats. Each has its own expectations & performance needs
@disruptivedean with best effort you can't sell video
@lgambardella Indeed. And it should remain so. Ideas of eg applying differential QoS to Internet apps are unworkable & undesirable
@disruptivedean I hope that you understand that Internet is best effort
RT @disruptivedean: @lgambardella Telcos don't always realise it, but they can/do  benefit from Neutrality as much as other actors. It's a …
@lgambardella Telcos don't always realise it, but they can/do  benefit from Neutrality as much as other actors. It's a level playing field

@lgambardella Also, companies pay me to understand if they should change their position. I'm not paid to promote their existing views
@disruptivedean but their position it's very different from your
@lgambardella Some of my clients seem to think so. Or at least a source of self-consistent opinions & analysis with a good track record
@disruptivedean you are like a oracle?

@disruptivedean you never answer.

@lgambardella My main consulting clients are same groups though - telcos & vendors - as I advise on network/telco trends & product strategy
@lgambardella It's in my self-interest that telcos prosper (they're my clients) & Internet innovation is healthy (they're my biz enablers)
